messages: ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:36): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: are these likely to reach end users?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:37): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: or are these just test builds to see that the protocol actually works?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:38): wow, chrome dev channel is up to v12 now
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:38): Well presumably the intention is to roll the protocol out to end users eventually

ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:38): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yeah, I'm just wondering if it'd be better to have websockets in dev only builds, or only ship up to -76, until the protocol stablises
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:39): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Well that will happen if you increment the version number 8 times a year
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:40): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: It would be better for no one to ship -76
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: well, I'm more so meaning, -76 is the latest one to have shipped, right?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:40): (out of any vendor)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:40): Yeah, but only WebKit still ship
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): And it would be nice if they would stop
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): (off by default doesn't count)
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:41): so, webkit would be the only ones to maybe be implementing -06?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): How did you infer that?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:41): okay, well, I'm more meaning, is it worth my time implementing -06?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:42): It's not like WebKit are the only people that care about WS, they're just the only people shipping the broken version
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:42): I guess it depends on the value of your timer
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:43): well, if it means that end users get to make use of the product, and that it isn't deprecated without any use, then, that's time well spent
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): I have rather given up on the whole IETF thing since it became clear that there was no chance of anything I said having an effect
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:43): is anybody shipping any future versions of websockets yet?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:44): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yeah, it does seem like a gated community in an open web.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:44): Where by "future" you mean "current"?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:44): well, yeah, I guess
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:44): so, nothing currently is using -06?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:45): It seems Chrome has an implementation
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:45): I'm not aware that they actuallly ship it
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:51): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: would you say this looks accurate? https://github.com/miksago/node-websocket-server/wiki/Browser-Support
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:53): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: Opera shipped disabled by default
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:55): Chrome and Chromium should presumably be identical here
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (12:56): so that should be right? (updated)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:12): feels sorry for Opera brand people for the toilet seat logo refusing to die in the press and on third-party sites
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:35): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: have you gotten any new bug reports for parsing bugs since the FF4 release on the 22nd?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:39): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I noticed one myself
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:39): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: and there's one that's tied to UA sniffing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:40): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Firefox 4 doesn't reconstruct active formatting elements when it sees text in an HTML integration point
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:40): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I gave up on debugging the UA sniffing case after observing that it worked if I faked Chrome's UA string
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:42): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=644144
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:42): about the former bug, are there sites for which that has caused significant problems?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:42): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=643410
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:43): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: none known. I noticed it when I reviewed a spec change
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:43): looks at the bug reports
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:43): see also http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=12357
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:44): looks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:44): oh, and also https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=644034
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:44): that seems like an oversight
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): that's not good
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): whoah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): but you're WONTFIXing it?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:45): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: well, didn't break sites in the wild, so OK
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): ah, OK
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:46): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Firefox 4 complies with the spec, spec makes sense, no sites in the wild broken
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:46): one broken bank so far: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=643710

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:48): developers of bank sites as a class seem to be in constant competition with airline sites to prove who can come up with the most bizarre asshattedly broken code
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:48): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: we unbroke united.com before shipping
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:49): thanks
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:49): as a United customer I appreciate it :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: but you are a U.S. citizen, right? the bug affected only non-U.S. citizens
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:50): ah, OK
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: so what's the current target date for FF5?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:52): notices his Minefield is now at 4.2
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:53): I really wish we'd fix the prerelease UA strings to say what the stable version will say
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:54): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I can't find the date written anywhere, so I'll refrain from repeating hearsay from memory
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (13:57): I wonder if the quick evolution of version numbers will help killing the user agent sniffing based on version numbers
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (13:57): That would be nice.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): that would be an excellent outcome, yes
4d05dc3c4352ebe7593b536f2078cfe9 (13:58): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: June 22 I think
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:58): though the problems I see are more often based on browser name than number
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): like sites not working, because Firefox 4 doesn't have the substring "Safari" in the UA string
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): that's the most common one I've seen

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:01): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: btw, you might want to add wikia.com to the list of sites you will need to evangelize when Opera implements HTML5-compliant script execution. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=610369
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: thanks. Useful I already see a few bugs opened for wikia

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (14:21): > Drieu left Apple in March 2010, where he was the head of the company's rich media and applications group.
